Si uero accidit in osse satagie, aut comminuitur, extrahe.	 If indeed a fracture or break occurs outside the bone, apply external treatment.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Adiutorii.	 § Regarding the aid of healing fractures.
Caput XII.	 Head XII.
Adiutorium est illud, quod est inter cubitum usque ad caput Spatulae.	 The aids are those that exist from the elbow to the head of the scapula.
Si ergo frangitur, tunc restauratio eius est secundum unum duorum modorum.	 If therefore it breaks, then its healing is according to one or two kinds of methods.
Quorum unus est: ut accipias lignum planum mediae grossitudinis, secundum hanc formam, quae sequitur.	 One of which is: that you receive a plank wood of medium thickness according to this shape, which follows.
Et ligentur in duabus extremitatibus duo ligamenta.	 And two cords are tied at the two ends.
Deinde suspendatur ex loco eleuato: et sedeat infirmus super sedem.	 Then it is hung from an elevated place; and the sick one sits on the bed.
Deinde proiiciat brachium suum fractum super lignum, donec perueniat ad titillicum eius, in cuius medio sit annexa curuitas ligni.	 Then he throws his broken arm over the wood until it reaches near its elbow, with a sling attached in the middle of the wood.
Deinde suspende desuper ipsum aliquid graue, ut extendat ipsum minister ad inferiora.	 Then hang something light from above him to stretch himself towards the lower part.
Deinde aequet medicus fracturam manibus suis simul, donec redeat fractura, secundum quod oportet.	 Then the doctor equalizes the break with his hands at once until it is set right as needed.
Et modus alter est, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et suspende manum eius a collo ipsius cum ligamento.	 And another way is that the sick one lies supine over his own neck: and hangs his hand from his neck with a cord.
Deinde praecipe duobus ministris, ut teneat unus eorum illud quod est supra fracturam cum manibus suis: et ut alter teneat inferius eius, et extendat unusquisque eorum ad partem suam.	 Then command two ministers to keep one of them that is above the break with their hands: and let another hold it below him, and stretch each of them towards his own part.
Et si uis, ut sit extensio fortior, tunc stringe sub fractura cum ligamento, et supra ipsam cum ligamento alio: et extendat ea unusquisque duorum ministrorum ad duas partes suas.	 And if you want a stronger extension, then tighten under the break with a cord and above it with another cord: and let each of the two ministers stretch towards their own parts.
Si ergo fractura est propinqua extremitati humeri, tunc oportet, ut ponatur unum ligamentum sub titillico, et alterum sub fractura uersus cubitum.	 If therefore the break is near the end of the shoulder, then it is appropriate that one sling be placed under its elbow and another against the break towards the arm's bend.
Et similiter si fractura est propinqua cubito: tunc oportet, ut ponatur ligamentum super illum locum, et super cubitum ipsum.	 And similarly, if there is a fracture near the elbow: then it must be arranged that a ligament is placed above that place, and over the arm itself.
Deinde aequa fracturam cum facilitate absque labore, donec quando aequatur fractura secundum quod oportet, et applicatur applicatione bona: tunc stringe eam, si non accidit apostema calidum.	 Then an equal fracture with ease and without effort, until the faster is balanced as it should be, and a good treatment is applied: then bind it tightly, unless hot pus occurs.
Si uero accidit apostema calidum, tunc dimitte stricturam usque ad diem septimum.	 But if indeed there occurs hot pebylic stricture until the seventh day.
Et pone super ipsum lanam succidam imbibitam in aceto et oleo rosato, donec quando quiescit apostema: tunc stringe eam: et modus stringendi eam est, ut ponas emplastrum super fracturam.	 And place on the above a soaked woolen cloth imbibed in vinegar and rose oil, until when the pustule rests: then bind it: and the manner of binding is to place a plaster over the fracture.
Deinde pone inuolutionem ex panno nouo super emplastrum.	 Then place an unrolling from new cloth over the plaster.
Deinde aggreget brachium super adiutorium ipsum, et ponat manum suam apertam super humerum suum.	 Then gather the arm over support itself and place his open hand over his upper arm.
Et pone pannum, et stringe super adiutorium brachium, ut brachium stet loco astellarum: si non prohibet te ab illo aliquid, neque alteretur super te aliquid ex osse fracto.	 And place the cloth and bind it over the arm support so that the arm stands in place of the stars: if nothing prevents you from it, nor does anything change for you above the broken bone.
Quod si times, quod alteretur super te ex osse fracto aliquid, tunc utere astellis: et est, ut ponas super fracturam ipsam astellam quae sit latior et fortior reliquis astellis.	 But if it happens that something is changed over you from the broken bone, then use the stars: and this is to place on top of the same star that is wider and stronger than the rest of the stars.
Et ponas inter omnem astellam latitudinem digiti: et sit longitudo astellarum secundum fracturam cum additione trium digitorum ab omni parte.	 And place between every star the width of the finger: and be the length of the stars according to the broken bone with an addition of three fingers from all sides.
Deinde stringe super astellas strictura quam dixi in principio capituli.	 Then bind over the stars the tightening that I said at the beginning of this chapter.
Et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae strictior.	 And it is to be your binding on top of the place of the broken bone firmer.
Et quanto plus elongatur fractura, sit strictura minor.	 And as much more the broken bone stretches out, let there be a lighter binding.
Si ergo uides situm astellarum et stricturam, sicut diximus, in hora qua restauras membrum statim, tunc fac: et si times apostema calidum, tunc dimitte stricturam et astellas usque ad diem septimum, sicut diximus.	 But if indeed you see the position of the stars and the binding as we said, at the time when you immediately restore the limb, then do: and if hot pebylic stricture occurs, then release the binding and the stars until the seventh day, as we said.
Deinde considera ligamentum in omnibus tribus diebus, ut non accidat in loco pruritus, aut inflatio, aut prohibeatur cibus peruenire ad membrum, propter dispositionem superfluitatis stricturae.	 Then consider the ligament for all three days so that itching does not occur at the place, or swelling, or food is prevented from reaching the limb due to the position of excessive tightening.
Rectifica ergo illud totum, secundum quod diximus.	 Thus corrects everything as we have said.
Si uero es super fiduciam, ut non accidat ex illo aliquid: tunc non soluas ligamentum, nisi post tres dies, aut plus.	 If indeed you are reliable, so that nothing occurs from it: then do not loosen the ligament unless after three days or more.
Et sit dormitio infirmi super dorsum suum, et manus eius super stomachum suum: et pone sub adiutorio culcitram plenam lana aequaliter.	 And let the sick person sleep on their back, and their hand over their belly; and place a fully filled wool cushion under them evenly with help.
Et considera in omni hora noctis, aut diei, ut non soluatur figura membri fracta, aut mollificetur ligamentum.	 And consider at all hours of the night or day that the shape of the broken bone does not loosen and that the ligament is softened.
Rectifica ergo illud totum uirtute tua.	 Thus corrects everything with your strength.
Et pone cibum infirmi secundum ordinem quem praemisimus, ita ut sit cibus subtilis in primis, donec incipiat os stringi: tunc oportet, ut ingrosses cibum eius.	 And place food for the sick person according to the order we have mentioned so that it is subtle food first until their mouth tightens; then it must be that they eat thickened food.
De consuetudine enim adiutorii et cruris est, ut stringatur in quadraginta diebus: tunc ergo oportet, ut soluatur, et administretur balneum, et medicetur cum unguentis quae rectificant illud.	 For it is the custom of assistance and for the leg to be tightened for forty days: then indeed it must be loosened, given a bath, and treated with ointments that correct it.
Quod si fractura fuerit foeda, attrita: tunc non soluas ab ea ligamentum et astellas usque ad quinquaginta dies, et usque ad duos menses.	 If the fracture were dirty, cleanse it: then do not loosen the ligament and staples until fifty days and until two months.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Brachii.	 ¶ On healing a bone fracture of the arm.
Caput XIII.	 Head XII.
Brachium est compositum ex duobus ossibus, quae nominantur duo focilia.	 The arm is composed of two bones called ulna and radius.
Quorum unum est paruum: et est illud quod sequitur pollicem.	 One of which is longer: and it is that which follows the thumb.
Et alterum est magnum, et est illud quod est positum sub paruo ab inferiori parte.	 And the other is larger, and it is that which is placed under the little one from its lower part.
Fortasse ergo frangitur focile maius solum, aut paruum: et fortasse franguntur simul.	 Therefore the larger bone breaks easily alone, or the smaller one: and perhaps they break at the same time.
Quando ergo frangitur focile paruum superius, tunc restauratio eius est facilis, et sanatio eius est facilior.	 Whenever therefore the upper part of a fracture is broken, then its restoration is easy, and its healing is easier.
Et quando frangitur focile inferius, est fractura eius mala, et sanatio eius difficilis.	 And when the lower part of a fracture breaks, that fracture is bad, and its healing is difficult.
Et deterior ea est, quando franguntur duo ossa simul.	 And worse it is, when two bones break simultaneously.
Si ergo os quod frangitur est focile parum superius, tunc conuenit medico apud restaurationem eius, ut ponat extensionem paruam cum facilitate, donec aequet ipsum.	 But if the bone that is broken has little above it be easy, then it behoovangs physicians to attend its restoration, so as to place an extension easily until it heals.
Si uero focile magnum est illud quod fractum est: tunc oportet, ut ponat stricturam fortiorem ualde.	 But if indeed that which is broken is large and easy: then one ought to place a stronger binding very firmly.
Et oportet, ut ponat figuram manus apud restaurationem eius, et ipsius extensionem extensam super puluinar.	 And it behooves to place the hand's form in its restoration and the stretching of itself upon cushions.
Et sit pollex manus ad superiora altior omnibus digitis: et sit articularis inferior omnibus digitis, uel reliquis: et infirmus sedens quadratus super seipsum, et sit puluinar coram eo, uel in directo eius, in altitudine, ut non incurrat infirmus laborem.	 And let the thumb of the hand be higher than all other fingers: and let the jointed be lower than all other fingers, or others: and the weak sitting squared over itself, and have cushions before it, or in line with its height, so that not a laborious infirmity may occur.
Deinde extendat minister Brachium ab inferiori parte, aut manu sua, aut cum ligamento.	 Then let the servant stretch the arm from the lower part, or with his hand, or with a bandage.
Et minister alius extendat desuper similiter.	 And another minister stretches similarly from above.
Deinde aequet medicus os, donec reducat ipsum secundum meliorem figuram quam potest.	 Then the physician straightens the bone until he restores it to as good a form as possible.
Quod si in fractura ossis sunt satagiae, tunc conare reducere omne frustum in loco suo uirtute tua.	 Which if in the bone's fracture there are splinters, then strive to reduce every fragment to its place with your own strength.
Si uero apparet in eo sathaiatum separatum, et pungit cutem, et non est tibi spes in restauratione eius: tunc finde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum secundum modum quem diximus in eis quae praemissa sunt.	 But if indeed a separate splinter appears and pricks the skin, and there is no hope for its restoration with you: then find above it, and remove it according to the method which we have mentioned before these prefaces.
Si autem fractura est cum uulnere, ego iam feci ad illud capitulum singulare, ergo accipe curationem illius inde.	 But if indeed the fucture is with a wound, I have already made this separate chapter, therefore take the healing from there.
Quod si accidat in principio tuae restaurationis apostema calidum, tunc line pannum cum caeroto facto ex oleo rosato, et caera alba, et sit medium inter spissitudinem et subtilitatem: et stringe pannum super ipsum strictura subtili, donec quando sedatur apostema: tunc remoue caerotum, et pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum albumine oui.	 Which if in the beginning of your restoration a suppurate wound occurs, then line cloth with warm pitch made from rosary oil and white wax, and let it be medium between thickness and fineness: and stretch the cloth over the delicate binding, until when the suppuration is set: then remove the wax, and place an ointment prepared from mill dust and egg whites.
Deinde pone astellas, et sit astella quae ponitur super fracturam ipsam latior parumper, et fortior.	 Then place stars and let the star placed over the fracture itself be slightly wider and stronger.
Et scias, quod numerus astellarum Brachii est sex in pluribus dispositionibus: siue sit fractura in focili uno, aut in duobus focilibus simul.	 And know that the number of stars for the arm is six when arranged in multiple positions: if it's a fracture in one bar or two bars at once.
Deinde pone stricturam tuam super locum fracturae fortiorem et uehementiorem, et aliquanto plus cum strictura ad superiora fracturae, aut ad inferiora eius: aut pone stricturam molliorem strictura eius parumper, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius in principio capituli.	 Then place your splint over the stronger and more intense part of the fracture, and much closer to either the upper or lower part of the fracture: or place a somewhat softer splint than that, according to what was mentioned at the beginning of this chapter.
Et sint panni qui inuoluuntur super fracturam, panni lenes, humidi: et non sint duri, asperi.	 And let there be cloths covering the fracture, soft and moist: and they should not be hard or rough.
Et sit filum quo stringitur ex lino proprie, medium inter subtile et grossum, sicut narrauimus.	 And let the thread used for binding be made of linen itself, a medium between fine and coarse, as we have described.
Et considera membrum et ligamentum post dies.	 And consider the limb and the tendon after days.
Quod si accidat aliquid cuius rectificatio sit necessaria, sicut pruritus qui accidit membro: tunc oportet, ut embroces membrum cum aqua calefacta, donec quiescat ille pruritus, et dimittas membrum non constrictum, donec quiescat, deinde itera stricturam.	 That if something occurs which requires correction, such as itching that happens to the limb: then one must embrocate the limb with heated water until the itch subsides, and release the unbandaged limb, until it rests; then repeat the splinting.
Quod si strictura iam mollificata est, et os iam remotum, et similia illis: tunc rectifica illud totum uirtute tua, et considera iterum.	 That if the bandage is already softened, and the bone is already removed, and such like: then correct that whole thing with your strength, and examine it again.
Nam si nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad membrum, propter superfluitatem stricturae, tunc oportet, ut mollifices ipsum parumper, et dimittas ipsum aliquot diebus, donec currat ad ipsum nutrimentum, deinde stringe ipsum.	 For if nourishment is prevented from reaching the limb, because of the excessive bandage: then you must soften it somewhat, and release it for a few days, until it reaches nourishment; then bind it again.
Si autem non accidit infirmo aliquid eorum quae diximus, tunc non oportet, ut soluatur, nisi post uiginti dies, aut circiter hos.	 If however nothing of that kind occurs which we have mentioned to the weakened person: then it is not necessary for it to be dissolved, unless after nineteein days or so.
Deinde suspendatur manus infirmi ad collum eius.	 Then hang the sickly hand on his neck.
Et sit collum eius aequale, et custodiatur uirtute sua a motibus agitatiuis.	 And his neck shall be balanced, and he should guard himself against violent movements.
Et fac eum dormire super dorsum suum.	 Let him lie down on his back.
Et scias, quod haec fractura in triginta diebus, aut in triginta duobus diebus restauratur: et fortasse restauratur in uigintiocto diebus.	 And know that this fracture will be restored in thirty days or perhaps in twenty-eight days.
Totum illud est secundum dispositiones complexionum, et dispositiones uirtutis.	 It is all according to the constitutions and temperaments.
¶ De restauratione fracturarum Manus.	 ¶ Regarding the restoration of hand fractures.
Caput XIIII.	 Head XVII. (Note: The numbering 'XIV
Scias, quod pectini Manus, et nodis digitorum raro accidit fractura.	 Know that rarely does a fracture occur in the hand's phalanges and knuckles.
Et non accidit ei, nisi attritio multotiens.	 And it happens to him not except by frequent friction.
Quando ergo accidit plantae fractura, aut attritio: tunc oportet, ut sedeat infirmus quadratus: et coram eo sit sedes secundum aequalitatem.	 Whenever the sole of the foot is fancied or friction, then it must be that he lies supine with the affected area elevated evenly and in balance.
Deinde pone Manum eius super eam extensam.	 Then lay his hand on an extended surface.
Deinde extendat minister ossa fracta, et aequet ea medicus, donec quando coniunguntur coniunctione bona.	 Next the attendant extends the broken bones and joins them with proper healing until they are adequately united.
Tunc oportet, ut ponat emplastrum et stuppam, si non accidat apostema calidum.	 Then it must be that a bandage and plaster should be placed unless hot swelling occurs.
Deinde pone astellam desuper secundum quantitatem loci: et tu iam inuoluisti eam in panno lini.	 Then place the pillow above according to the size of the location, and now you have already enveloped it with linen cloth.
Si autem fractura est ad inferiora circiter uentrem plantae, tunc fac simile spherae ex panno: et praecipe infirmo, ut coartet super eam cum planta sua fracta: deinde stringatur cum panno longo.	 But if the fracture is around near the lower part of the foot, then make a similar sphere from cloth: and instruct the patient to place it with his broken sole: then it is fastened with long linen.
Et sit astella ex corio, in quo sit lenitas, ut applicetur corium cum corpore plantae: et stringe eam, secundum quod oportet.	 And the pillow shall be of leather where there is flexibility so that it can be applied to skin with the sole: and fasten it as required.
Si autem fractura est ad exteriora, tunc oportet: ut ponas astellam desuper, et astellam aliam ab inferiori in planta: et sit manus aperta recta.	 But if the fucture is on the outside, then it should be that you place a pillow above and another below at the footbed: and keep the hand open straight.
Deinde pone stricturam, sicut reuoluitur manus: et extende inter digitos cum ligamento.	 Then place a binding as usual for turning hands: and extend between fingers with a bandage.
Quod si accidat fractura alicui nodorum digitorum, tunc si est pollex, aequetur secundum quod oportet.	 "If there is a fracture to any finger joints, then if it is the thumb, they should be set as necessary.
Deinde stringatur cum planta: et si amas, pone ei astellam rectam, paruam: ut eleuetur fractura, et non moueatur.	 "Then it is bound with a bandage; and if one wishes to immobilize it, place therein a straight stick or rod, so that the fcuature may be set, and not moved.
Si autem fractura est reliquis digitis, sicut medio, et indici, aut auriculari, et anulari, tunc aequetur, et ligetur cum digito sano qui sequitur eum: aut ligentur omnes secundum continuationem: et est melius.	 "If the fracture is in any other fingers, such as the middle, index, ring, or little finger, then it should be set and bound with a healthy adjacent finger that follows it; or they can all be tied together according to their sequence; this is better.
Aut pone super ipsum astellam paruam, sicut diximus in pollice.	 "Or place upon it a thin rod as we mentioned for the thumb.
Et considera in restauratione tua, et post ipsam dispositionem apostematis calidi: et oppone cum eo quod oportet, quando accidit aliquid ex illo, secundum quod iteratur eius narratio.	 "And consider this in your treatment; and after the application of a warm poultice: then apply what is needed therewith when something arises from it, according to its course.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Coxae.	 "§ On the healing of hip fractures.
Caput XV.	 "Chapter 15.
OS Coxae multotiens frangitur, et declaratur sensui: quoniam conuertitur ad interiorem et posteriorem partem.	 "The pelvis often breaks and is characterized by this: because it turns to the inner and back parts.
Et restauratio eius fit ita, quod stringitur ligamentum supra fracturam, et ligamentum aliud sub fractura.	 "And its restoration is such that above the break it is tied with a ligament, and another ligament below the break.
Et infirmus prostretur super faciem suam.	 "And the weak one should be propped up on his own face.
Deinde extendat omne ligamentum minister ad partem suam secundum aequalitatem: et hoc, quando est fractura in medio ossis.	 "Then every attending ligament stretches to its side by equal measures; and this when there is a break in the middle of the bone.
Si autem est fractura propinqua radici Coxae, tunc sit ligamentum ad partem pectinis, ut cadat extensio ad sursum: et ligamentum aliud sub fractura.	 "If however there is a break near the root of the pelvis, then one ligament to the side of the pubic bone so that extension falls upward: and another ligament below the break.
Et sic similiter si est fractura propinqua genu, tunc sit ligamentum propinquum genu, ut sit extensio ad inferiora.	 "And thus similarly if there is a break near the knee, then one ligament close to the knee so that extension falls downward.
Deinde aequet medicus os utriusque manibus suis, donec reducat ipsum secundum similitudinem figurae naturalis: et coniugatur os coniunctione bona.	 "Then the physician sets both bones with his own hands until he restores it to its resemblance of its natural shape: and joins the bone together by a good union.
Tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum et stricturam, si non accidit membro apostema.	 Then it is necessary to place a plaster and a bandage, if no suppuration occurs in the limb.
Quod si accidat in eo apostema: tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur apostema calidum, deinde redi ad curationem tuam.	 If an abscess occurs there: then release it for several days, until the suppuration becomes warm, then return to your treatment.
Strictura autem eius ita sit.	 However, let that bandage be so.
Oportet ut inuoluas super fracturam imema duram, id est, bindam: et dupla eam bis, aut ter: et remaneat ex ea superfluitas.	 It is necessary to apply a linen strip over the hard-set fracture, that is, a bandage; and two of it twice or thrice: and let there be an excess remaining from it.
Deinde inuolue crus, donec perueniat calcaneus apud radicem natis.	 Then apply the linen strip to the leg, until it reaches the heel near the root of the buttocks.
Et intromitte filum longum inter Coxam et crus prope genu ad inferiora, et ueniant extremitates fili a superiori parte duarum partium.	 And insert a long thread between the hip and the leg near the knee to the lower side, and let the ends of the thread come from the upper parts of both limbs.
Deinde reuolue super Crus et Coxam quod superfluit ex alimema.	 Then roll it over the leg and the hip with the excess from the linen strip.
Deinde pone super Coxam in loco fracturae ipsius astellas, et pone ex eis astellam unam super os cruris.	 Then place on the hip at the site of its own stakes, and place one of them over the shin bone.
Deinde imple uacuitates inter crus et coxam cum pannis lenibus, ut aequetur strictura.	 Then fill with dampness between the leg and the hip with soft cloths so that it equalizes with the bandage.
Deinde incipe cum strictura forti a medio super locum fracturae tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor.	 Then start by fixing the strong bandage from the middle over the site of the break with three rolls or four.
Et quanto plus elongaris cum ligamento a loco fracturae, sit strictura tua minor et mollior, et lenior.	 And as much longer you extend with the cord from the place of the break, let your bandage be smaller and softer, and lighter.
Deinde intende ad duas extremitates fili, quod tu intromisisti inter coxam et crus.	 Then approach to the two ends of the thread that you inserted between the hip and leg.
Liga ergo cum utrisque tres astellas quae sunt desuper.	 Thus tie with both three stakes that are above them. (Note: The Latin text provided seems to be incorrect or incomplete, as "tres astellas" does not make sense in
Deinde uade cum duabus extremitatibus fili ad inferiora, donec peruenias ad cauillam pedis.	 Then proceed with the two lower ends of the thread until you reach the heel of the foot.
Et cum utrisque stringe etiam extremitates astellarum a parte altera: ut non remoueatur ligamentum ex loco suo.	 And also tighten both endings and again with the stakes on one side, so that the cord is not removed from its place.
Deinde dimitte stricturam super illud, dum permanet, ita quod non accidat membro corrosio, neque apostema, neque inflatio, et similia eis.	 Then release the bandage over that area while remaining, so that no ulceration occurs in the limb, nor an abscess, nor swelling, or similar things therein.
Quod si accidat aliquid ex illo.	 In case something happens from it.
Propera ergo cum solutione eius, et rectifica illud quod accidit inde totum, secundum quod diximus multotiens.	 Therefore, approach this with its solution and correct everything that happened thereafter as we have often said many times.
Si uero in osse est frustum ex osse quod pungat: tunc oportet, ut aeques illud, si est tibi possibile.	 If indeed there is a piece of bone shattered from the bone that pierces: then it should be leveled by you if possible.
Et si non, finde super illud, et remoue illud: et cura cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio, donec sanetur.	 And if not, find above it and remove that; and care for the person to whom it occurred until healed.
Et quandoque stringitur haec fractura Coxae, praeter quod addantur ei astellae, sicut diximus in adiutorio et brachio.	 And sometimes this fracture of the hip is bound, apart from adding to it small pieces as we have said with an assistant and a strap.
Verumtamen in restauratione eius taliter fracta, non accidit infirmo claudicatio.	 However, during its restoration, such broken things do not cause lameness.
Et si restauratur sola, praeter quod applicetur ei crus alterum, tunc necesse est, ut claudicet ille cuius est, semper.	 And if it is restored alone, apart from applying to it a second leg, then it is necessary for him whose it is to always be lame.
Et scias, quod Coxa stringitur in quinquaginta diebus, uel additur parum, aut minuitur parum: totum illud est secundum diuersitatem complexionum, et reliquarum dispositionum.	 And you know that the hip is bound for fifty days, or it adds little, or decreases little: all this depends on different temperaments and other dispositions.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Rotulae genu.	 ¶ Regarding the restoration of a broken ankle.
Caput XVI.	 Chapter XVI.
Scias, quod Rotulae genu raro accidit fractura, sed accidit ei attritio multotiens.	 Know that a fracture of the ankle's knee rarely happens but often by rubbing against it.
Si uero accidit ei fractura, tunc non nisi aut fissura, aut foramen in partibus suis.	 If indeed a fracture happens to it, then only a crack or hole within its parts.
Et est illud cum uulnere, et absque uulnere.	 And it is with a wound, and without a wound.
Et statur super illud totum cum sensu.	 And it stands above that completely with sense.
Et restauratio eius est ita, ut aequetur quod disruptum est ex partibus eius cum digitis, donec aggregetur, et coniungatur secundum quod possibile est ex aequatione et facilitate, et fabricatione.	 And its restoration is as follows: it becomes equal to what was broken from its parts with fingers, until joined together, and united according to what is possible by proportion and ease, and construction.
Deinde pone emplastrum ex farina sisami, uel molendini, cum albumine oui: et pone super ipsum astellam rotundam, si indiges illa: et stringe desuper strictura conueniente ad illud.	 Then place a plaster from the flour of Sisam (a type of millet), or mill, with egg white: and place over it a round strap if you find that one: and bind above that suitable strapping to this.
Deinde considera omnes dispositiones quas narrauimus in reliquis fracturis: sicut apostema calidum, et similia illi: ita, ut opponas omni accidenti cum eo quod conuenit ei, donec sanetur.	 Then consider all the arrangements that we have described in previous fractures: such as a hot boil, and similar things: so that you oppose every accident with whatever is suitable for it until healed.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Cruris.	 On restoring the broken leg.
Caput XVII.	 Chapter amo.untenseventeenth
Scias, quod Cruri sunt duo ossa, quorum unum est grossum, et nominatur nomine Cruris: et alterum subtile, et nominatur Focile.	 Know that there are two bones of the leg, one is thick and named by its kind as the thigh (Crus), and the other is slender and called Shinbone (Femur).
Et accidit utrisque ex speciebus fracturae quod accidit duobus ossibus brachii: et propter illud fit restauratio eius, sicut restauratio brachii aequaliter, et operatio est una.	 And it happens to both kinds of fractures as with the two bones of the arm: and because of this, its restoration is made like that of the arm's equally, and the operation is one.
Quod si franguntur duo ossa simul, conuertitur Crus ad omnes partes.	 That if both bones are broken at once, the thigh (Crus) turns to all parts.
Et si frangitur os subtilius, conuertitur Crus ad anteriorem partem.	 And if the slender bone is fractured, the thigh (Crus) converts to the front part.
Et si frangitur os grossius, inuenis illud inferius: et est ex eis quae non occultantur tibi.	 And if the thick bacteria are broken, you find it below: and it is among those that do not hide from you.
Deinde administra extensionem, et aequationem, et ligationem astellarum secundum illud aequaliter.	 Then apply extension, and adjustment, and the binding of wires similarly equal.
Verumtamen oportet, si fractura Cruris est fractura foeda, habens sethagie multa: ut sit extensio minor, et lenior alleuiatione tua.	 However, it is necessary if the leg's fracture has many dirty wounds (septic): so that there should be less extension and your relief milder.
Et in Crure quidem est ex operatione quiddam super brachium: et est, ut quando tu aequas astellas, et comples omnem operationem tuam, tunc accipe duas fascias ex ligno pini, quod administratur in fabricatione solariorum quod ponitur sub tabulis: et fiunt ex spatulis palmae: et elige ex eis quibus est grossitudo parua, et neque sint ex minutis: et sit longitudo earum secundum longitudinem Cruris a genu usque inferius.	 And indeed the operation on the leg is somewhat above that of the arm: and it is as when you put equal wires in your work with sun shades, which are placed under boards: and they are made from palm leaves: and choose among them those who have small thickness, and are not too fine. And their length should be according to the length of the leg from the knee downwards.
Deinde inuolue super unamquamque pannum duabus inuolutionibus secundum longitudinem eius.	 Then wrap over both skins with two folds according to their length.
Et pone unam partem Cruris a parte una, et alteram a parte altera: et sint ex genu usque inferius pedis.	 And place one part of the shank on one side from the upper knee to below the foot.
Deinde liga duas fascias in tribus locis ex duabus extremitatibus et medio.	 Then tie two bandages at three places, from both ends and the middle.
Cum enim strictura prohibetur, Crus declinat ad dextram et sinistram, et stat statione bona.	 For since constriction is forbidden, the shank slopes to the right and left, and stands in a good position.
Et iam quidem administretur cunabulum ex ligno secundum longitudinem Cruris, et ponatur in eo Crus, ut conseruet ipsum a motu.	 And indeed it would be provided with a cradle from wood according to the length of the shank, and placed in such a way that it preserves itself from movement.
Et plurimum quidem oportet, ut facias illud in fractura quando cum ea est uulnus proprie.	 And indeed it is very important to make this when the fracture is accompanied by its own wound.
Deinde considera Crus in omni die, et stude cum eo studio ultimo ab apostemate, aut inflatione, aut reliquis aliis.	 Then consider the shank every day and study it carefully with regard to the end of swelling or inflammation, or any other things.
Si ergo accidit aliquid ex illis, tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur, si Deus uoluerit.	 If therefore something happens from those, then oppose to it with what is needed, until healed, if God wills so.
De fractura ossium Pedis, et Digitorum.	 About the fracture of bones of the foot and fingers.
Caput XVIII.	 Chapter 18.
Calcaneo quidem non accidit fractura penitus.	 However, not a complete fracture of the heel has occurred.
Ossibus uero Pedis accidit quandoque fractura, et Digitis parum etiam accidit fractura: et non accidit eis nisi attritio in pluribus dispositionibus.	 However, a fracture of the foot bones occurs sometimes, and also a slight fracture of the fingers: and it does not occur to them except friction in several dispositions.
Quod si accidit ossibus Pedis fractura, et uides illa ossa sublimari super se adinuicem, tunc ponat infirmus Pedem suum super terram praeparatam, sicut ambulans.	 That if a fracture of the foot bones occurs and you see that those bones raise themselves above their own swelling to some extent, then the sick should place his foot over the prepared ground as walking.
Deinde sta tu, et pone Pedem tuum super illud quod eleuatur ex illis ossibus: postea preme, uel calca eam: et aequa ipsam, donec redeat in locis suis.	 Then stand still and place your foot over that which is elevated from those bones: afterwards press it, or strike it with the heel; and let it remain equal until it returns to its places.
Deinde pone emplastrum, et stuppam desuper: et pone sub uentre Pedis tabulam paruam, cui sint duo capita plana.	 Then place a paste, and a band above: and place under the foot a thin board with two flat heads.
Deinde stringe eam cum Pede strictura decenti, postquam tu inuoluis eam cum pannis, et reliquis quibus indiget.	 Then tie it tightly with a suitable constriction after you have warmed it with bandages and other things it needs.
Cum ergo praetereunt ei tres dies, aut quatuor, tunc solue ligamentum.	 Therefore, when three or four days have passed by, then loosen the bandage.
Nam tu inuenies ossa aequata, siue sint fracta, aut sint dislocata.	 For if you find even bones, whether they are broken or displaculed.
Operatio ergo in eis est, sicut uides.	 Therefore the operation is as follows, which you see.
Si autem franguntur aliqui digiti, tunc restaura eos, et aequa ipsos secundum quod narraui tibi in restauratione digitorum manus.	 But if some fingers are broken, then restore them and straighten the same according to what you have described for restoring the fingers of the hand.
Deinde pone digito tuo astellam secundum longitudinem digiti, et sit latior eo parumper: deinde pone sub Pede hanc tabulam quam narraui tibi, et stringe eam strictura decenti.	 Then place your own splint according to the length of the finger, and it should be a little wider; then place underfoot this table that you described, and tie it with an appropriate bandage.
Si uero quod frangitur ex ossibus est duo, aut tria, aut plus, tunc pone super omnem digitum astellam suae quantitatis, inuolutam in panno lini: et stringe tabulam in inferiori Pedis: et sit stans super unum capitum tabulae extra uentrem Pedis, ut teneat retentione bona.	 But if what is broken consists of two or three or more bones, then place over the entire finger a splint of its quantity in linen cloth; and tie the table at the bottom of the foot: and let it stand on one head of the table outside the lower part of the foot so that it may hold good retention.
Et conuenit tibi, ut non obliuiscaris, quin consideres omnia quae dixi tibi in reliquis fracturis ex accidentibus quae diximus: et oppone omni accidenti cum eo quod oportet.	 And it is fitting for you not to forget that you should consider everything I have said to you regarding the remaining broken things from accidents which we have discussed: and apply each remedy with what is suitable.
¶ De fractura Vuluae mulieris, et ossis pectinis, et uirgae uiri.	 § On the fracture of the woman's vulva, and the bone of the pelvis, and the thighbone of a man.
Caput XIX.	 Head 1e.
Quando frangitur Vulua mulieris, tunc fac eam sedere quadratam.	 When the woman's vulva is broken, then make it sit in a square position.
Deinde inclina eam ad partem dorsi ipsius parumper, et teneatur retro.	 Then lean her towards her own back somewhat, and she should be held behind.
Deinde impleat obstetrix Vuluam eius coto, donec impleat eam: et fiat in Vulua ex eo sicut sphera.	 Then the midwife shall fill its own womb with cotton until it is filled; and let it be made in the vulva as a sphere.
Deinde concutiatur mulier, et eleua dorsum eius paulatim.	 Then shake the woman, and support her back gradually.
Illud enim cotum egreditur, donec fiat ante portam Vuluae sicut sphera, et os fractum redit.	 For indeed that cotton is expelled until it becomes before the vulva as a sphere, and the broken bone returns.
Deinde pone puluillum super dorsum eius.	 Then place a poultice on his back.
Quando ergo uult mingere, remoueat cotum cum facilitate, deinde mingat: et reduc ipsum secundum modum, quo intromisisti ipsum in primis: deinde redeat ad puluillum suum primum.	 Whenever he wishes to urinate, remove the catheter with ease, then let him urinate; and return it according to the method by which you first inserted it; then let him go back to his poultice.
Faciat illud septem diebus, aut circiter, os ipsum enim restauratur.	 Do this for seven days or so, because the mouth is restored in this manner.
Et si uis, accipe uesicam ouis, et stringe super foramen eius cannulam arundinis, et intromitte uesicam totam in Vuluam eius.	 And if you wish, take a sheath on the mouth and tie a cord over its hole with a reed tube, then insert the entire sheeht into his urethra.
Deinde suffla in cannulam cum uirtute, donec infletur uesica intra Vuluam, fractura enim redit.	 Then blow gently into the tube until it inflates inside the urethra, for this way a rupture is healed.
Deinde impleatur cum coto, et stet aliquot diebus, secundum quod narrauimus, donec sanetur.	 Then fill with cotton and let it stay for several days as we have said, until it is healed.
Et quando frangitur os Pectinis uiri, aut mulieris, tunc administra in restauratione eius, et ipsius aequatione illud quod narrauimus in osse Anchae.	 And when the pelvic bone of a man or woman is broken, then apply this remedy for its restoration, and also that proportion we have mentioned in the healing of a skull fracture.
Et non occultatur rectum in his fracturis propinquis, quae parum contingunt, praecipue cui est quiddam studii, uel usus.	 And do not neglect the anus near these fractures that are somewhat close together, especially those having something to do with study or use.
Et intellige librum meum istum multum, quoniam fractura ipsa significat tibi in pluribus dispositionibus uiam rectam in restauratione sui, et strictura sui: intellige ergo.	 And understand this book of mine much, for the fracture itself signifies to you many ways towards a straight path in its restoration and constriction: therefore understand it.
In Virga autem uiri quando frangitur, accipe guttur anseris: et intromitte uirgam in ipso.	 When the wing of a man is broken, take the neck of a goose; and insert the wing into it.
Deinde pone super ipsum inuolutionem ex panno, et inuoluatur, et dimittatur tribus diebus, aut circiter eos, et sanabitur, si Deus uoluerit.	 Then place a swelling on top of it from cloth and let it be inflamed; then release it for about three days or so, and it will heal if God wishes.
¶ De restauratione fracturae ossium, quando est cum uulnere.	 Of the restoration of a bone fracture when there is also an ulcer.
Caput XX.	 Head XX.
Conuenit ei cui accidit fractura cum uulnere, praecipue si est magnum, sicut os coxae, aut adiutorii, aut simile illi, ut properes, et phlebotomes ipsum statim: si attestantur tibi conditiones phlebotomiae, sicut praemisimus.	 It is suitable for him whose fracture has occurred with an ulcer, especially if it is large like the hip bone or its assistants, and similar to those, such as properies, and phlebotomists himself immediately: if the conditions of phlebotomy are shown to you, as we have mentioned before.
Quod si uulnus effluit sanguinem, tunc oportet, ut properes ad abscisionem eius, ita ut puluerizes super ipsum zegi tritum: si non est tibi praesens aliud.	 If a wound is flowing blood, then one should hasten to cut it off so that you rub powdered lime on top of it; if nothing else is present.
Deinde incipe restaurare fracturam in illo eodem die: et non postponas illud, si non accidit apostema.	 Then begin repairing the fracture on that same day: and do not delay this, unless an abscess occurs.
Si uero accidit apostema calidum, tunc dimitte restaurationem eius usque ad diem nonum, donec sedetur apostema.	 However, if a hot abscess occurs, then postpone the repair until the ninth day so that the abscess may settle.
Et non appropinques ei in die tertio, et quarto omnino, nam tu faceres ei accidere accidentia mala.	 And do not approach it on the third or fourth day at all, for you will bring about unfortunate events to him.
Si autem os fractum est eminens super cutem detectum: tunc oportet, ut coneris reducere ipsum, et aequare ipsum manibus tuis cum facilitate et extensione parua.	 But if the broken bone is protruding over the skin detected: then you should aim to reduce it, and make sure that your hands are able to do so with ease and slight pressure.
Si autem non praeparatur extensio eius, et ipsius aequatio manibus tuis: tunc reduc ipsum cum isto instrumento.	 But if there is no extension of it, and adjusting it with your hands: then reduce the bone using this instrument.
Et est instrumentum quod fit ex ferro, cuius longitudo est quantitas septem digitorum, aut octo: et eius latitudo est secundum quantitatem uulneris.	 And an instrument that is made of iron, whose length corresponds to the size of seven or eight fingers: and its width according to the amount of the wound.
Et propter illud necesse est medico, ut accipiat ex eis tria, aut quatuor secundum quantitatem qua indiget ad illud ex curatione in omni specie fracturae.	 And because of this it is necessary for the physician to receive from them three or four according to the amount he needs for that kind of treatment regarding any type of fracture.
Et sit rotundum: et sit in eo grossitudo parua, ut non duplicetur apud compressionem super ipsum in hora operationis: et sit acutae extremitatis, cui sit margo in extremitatibus suis.	 And it should be round; and its thickness small so that it does not double upon itself when compressed over the wound during surgery: and it should have a border on its ends.
Et sit superius eius ad grossitudinem ex medietate eius usque ad inferiora.	 And its upper part should be as thick as half of its total thickness down to the lower end.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its form.
Oportet in Hac Operatione, ut ponatur extremitas eius acuta curuata super extremitatem ossis eminentis: et impelle ipsum cum eo uice una, donec quando redit os et aequatur quadam aequatione.	 It should be placed during this operation that its sharp end is bent over the protruding bone edge: and push it in with one tool until when the bone returns and reaches an equal position.
Conare ergo aequare extremitates fracturae adinuicem.	 So try to equalize the edges of the fracture accordingly.
Quod si extremitates eius fracta est subtilis, et non accipit eam instrumentum accaeptione bona, tunc opotet, ut incidas extremitatem illius ossis, donec instrumentum potestatem habeat eius.	 If the ends of it are fractured in a subtle way and does not accept them by proper treatment, then you must cut into that bone until the tool has power over it.
Si uero non potes reducere eos cum eo quod narrauimus omnino, tunc incide ipsum cum eo quod conuenit ei ex Incisoriis quae diximus: aut serra ipsum cum una serrarum quocunque modo possibile est tibi.	 If indeed you cannot reduce them as we have described at all, then incise it with the instrument that is suitable for him from those incisors we mentioned: or saw it with a single saw of whatever kind is possible to you.
Deinde rade illud quod remanet in osse ex asperitate et corticibus minutis.	 Then scrape off that which remains on the bone due to roughness and small cortexes.
Cum ergo reducitur os, et inuenit infirmus post reductionem eius dolorem uehementem laedentem, tunc scias, quod os non rediit ad locum suum naturalem.	 But when the bone is reduced and finds that it has a very severe pain after the reduction of its weakness, then you know that the bumps have not returned to their natural place.
Fac ergo illud.	 Do that.
Nam tu confers infirmo iuuamentum magnum, cum completur restauratio tua quam facis ossi.	 For you are dealing with a large weakness in the patient when completing your restoration of the bone which you do.
Tunc submerge pannum in uino stiptico, nigro.	 Then immerse the bandage in astringent black wine.
Et proprie si est in aestate.	 And properly if it is summer. (This seems to be an incomplete sentence or fragment from the original text.)
Et non ponas super uulnus caerotum, neque aliquid in quo sit oleum: ut non faciat accidere in ipso putredinem et corruptionem.	 And do not place a greasy dressing on the wound, nor anything that has oil in it: so that it does not happen to decay and rot.
Deinde administra astellas in hora complementi tui a restauratione ossis.	 Then administer astillas at your time of completion of the bone restoration. (Note: "astillas" is unclear in this context; it may refer to an ancient treatment using crushed substances, but without additional
Et dimitte uulnus detectum: ita, ut incidas cum forficibus foramen in inuolutionibus secundum quantitatem uulneris.	 And dismiss the detected wound: so that you cut with forceps a hole according to the amount of the wound. (Note: The reference to "incidens" and "forceps" suggests an incision or excision procedure, but this is speculative without further medical context.)
Et caue omni cautela, ne stringas uulnus cum fractura.	 And beware of every precaution, not to tighten the wound with a fracture. (This sentence advises against applying pressure or dressing that may exacerbate a fractured area
Multotiens enim fecerunt istud stolidi medici: et fecerunt accidere super infirmos suos aut mortem, aut corrosionem, aut zuchem, id est, saniem.	 For they have done this foolishly often: and made it happen to their own sick people either death or decay or pustules, that is, health. (Note: This translation appears nonsensical; the phrase "id est, saniem" does not translate directly to "health." It's possible there may be a misunderstanding in the term "zuchem," which is unclear and may require further clarification or context for an accurate translation.)
Et sit strictura tua mollis, lenis, diuersa stricturae fracturarum reliquarum.	 And your ligature should be soft, gentle, a diverse rupture of other broken bones.
Quod si uulnus est malum, aut est uulnus magnum, et times super ipsum quaedam accidentia mala quae narrauimus, et inuenis dolorem in loco suspensum: tunc non oportet, ut ponas super ipsum astellas.	 If the wound is bad or it is a large wander and you encounter some adverse events that we have mentioned, and you find pain in a hanging place: then it should not be placed with spikes over it.
Et fac eis inuolutiones ex pannis duris in loco astellarum, et stringe ipsum cum eis.	 And do for them contractions from hard cloths at the place of spikes, and bind it tightly with them.
Cum autem est post diem unum, aut dies duos, et uides uulnus iam incipere, ut in eo generetur pus: tunc aufer desuper ipsum pannum quem posuisti super ipsum cum uino.	 However, if it is after one day or two days, and you see the wound beginning to generate pus: then remove above the cloth that was placed over it with wine.
Deinde administra licinia, et unguenta cum quibus de consuetudine nostra est, ut medicemur uulnera: sicut unguentum tetrapharmacon, et similia illi.	 Then apply a liniment and ointments with which it is our custom to treat wounds: such as the four-drug salve and similar things.
Et conuenit tibi, ut soluas ligamentum.	 And it suits you to dissolve the bandage.
Et considera uulnus in omni die mane et uespere, donec consolidetur, et sanetur.	 And observe the wound at every morning and evening until it is healed and cured.
Et oportet, ut praeparetur membrum taliter, ut currat ex eo pus ad inferiora cum facilitate.	 And it should be prepared so that the limb runs with pus to the lower parts easily.
Quod si praetereunt uulneri dies multi, et non consolidatur, neque abscinditur pus ab eo: tunc scias, quod illic sunt satagie ossis parua.	 If many wounds are passing and it is not healing, nor does the pcu separate from it: then you should know that there are slight bone fractures.
Quare oportet, ut inquiras uulnus cum tenta.	 Therefore, you must examine the wound with probing.
Quot uero ex illis alsatagie sunt separata, remoue ea, et extrahe ipsa.	 However, how many of them are separated: remove those and extract it (the pus).
Et quae ex eis sunt non separata, et pungunt membrum, et faciunt accidere dolorem, conare incidere ea, et auferre ea omni modo quo possibile est tibi illud.	 And those of them that are not separated and puncture the limb and cause pain, try to make them fall out, and remove them in every possible way you can do it.
Quod si accidat uulneri zuchen, aut ekileten, id est, estiomenus, aut species alia corruptionis et putrefactionis: tunc oportet, ut opponas unicuique ex eis cum eo quod conuenit ei ex curatione, cuius praecessit narratio in capitulo suo.	 If it happens that the wound is swollen or aired (leaks), that is, it has an outpouching, or other types of corruption and putrefaction: then you should apply to each of them with what suits him from treatment, according to which was explained in its own chapter.
Et ex eo in quo oportet ut stet sermo meus, et cui facias praesentem mentem tuam quando frangitur os, et eminet super membrum, sicut os coxae, et adiutorii, et similia eis ex membris magnis, est, ut non praesumas attractionem eius, multotiens enim accidit ex illo mors, imo dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat.	 And from this, to make my speech stay, and whom you should have in mind when a bone is broken, and protrudes over the limb, as with the pelvis of the hip, and helpers, and similarities from large limbs, it is so that you do not presume its attraction; for often enough many deaths occur from this, indeed let it go until putrefaction.
Fortasse enim cadet per se post uiginti dies, aut triginta.	 Perhaps after ninetee or thirty days, it may fall off by itself.
Tunc ergo cura uulnus, si uidetur tibi: et sinon, dimitte ipsum.	 Then indeed care for the wound if you see it: but otherwise let it go.
¶ De curatione Nodationis in uestigio fracturae.	 § For curing a nodule in the sign of bone fracture.
Caput XXI.	 Head XXI.
Multoties accidit haec Nodatio in uestigio sanationis fracturae.	 Often this Nodulation occurs in the sign of bone fracture healing.
Praecipue, quae est prope iuncturas: et foedatur ex ea figura membri.	 Especially, that which is near joints: and feeds from its shape on the body.
Et fortasse prohibet membrum ab operatione sua naturali.	 And perhaps it hinders the limb from its natural action.
Considera ergo tunc, si nodatio est recens: administra in ea medicinas quae stipticitatem habent, sicut aloe, et olibanum, et myrrha, et sarcocolla, et acacia, et similia eis.	 Consider then, if the Nodulation is recent: apply therein remedies that have astapecticity, such as aloe, and olibanum, and myrrh, and sarcocolla, and acacia, and similar substances from them.
Ita, ut accipias ex istis quasdam, aut omnes eas: et confice eas cum uino stiptico, aut cum albumine oui, aut cum aceto: et pone eas super nodationem in stuppa, et stringe eas super ipsam strictura bona.	 So that you may receive from these certain ones or all of them: and make them with astringent wine, or with albuminous milk, or with vinegar: and place them over the Nodulation on cotton wool, and tie them tightly over the same bandage.
Et dimitte stricturam, nec soluas eam diebus multis.	 And loosen the bandage, do not remove it for many days.
Deinde solue eam, et itera aliam, donec remoueatur nodatio.	 Then dissolve it and apply another one, until the Nodulation is removed.
Aut stringe super ipsam laminam plumbi decenter.	 Or tie over the same thin sheet of lead impartially.
Plumbo enim est proprietas remouendi omne quod timetur ex membris.	 For Lead indeed has a property to remove all that is feared from limbs.
Si autem nodatio iam in lapidem conuersa est, et stricta est, et festine prouocat necessitas ad auferendum eam: tunc finde super eam ex superiori parte eius, et incide superfluitatem eminentem: aut rade eam cum quibusdam rasoriis, donec remoueatur: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	 If however the Nodulation is already turned into stone and tightened, and urgently provokes necessity for removal of it: then cut over it from its upper part, and scrape off any excess that protrudes: or shave it with certain rasors until removed; care for it, until healed.
¶ De curatione quando restauratur, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, non secundum naturam suam.	 "Concerning healing when it is restored, and a member remains delicate, not according to its own nature.
Caput XXII.	 Chapter 22.
Quando restauratur fractura ossis, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, debile: tunc non fit illud nisi propter caussas multas.	 "When a bone is restored and the member remains delicate afterward, then it does not happen for no reason but due to many causes.
Quarum una est, multitudo solutionis ligamenti et ligationis eius non secundum quod oportet: aut propter superfluitatem stricturae ligamentorum, donec prohibeatur nutrimentum currere ad membrum: aut propter multitudinem embrocationis superfluae in non sua hora: aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore infirmi, et debilitatem eius.	 "One of the reasons is an excessive flow from ligament dissolution and its improper binding, which prevents nourishment from reaching the limb; or due to an overabundance of embrocation applied at inappropriate times; or because of a scarcity of blood within the sickly body, leading to weakness.
Et curatio illius est, cibare infirmum, et tenerum facere corpus eius, donec multiplicetur sanguis in eo.	 "And therefore, healing it involves nourishing the sick body and making its form tender until blood increases therein.
Et administra balneum.	 "And apply a bath.
Et intromitte gaudium et laeticiam super eum.	 "And instill joy and gladness upon him.
Deinde pone picem super membrum: ut attrahat pix ad ipsum nutrimentum multum.	 "Then place pitch on the limb, so that it will draw in a great deal of nourishment.
Et assiduet embrocationem eius cum aqua tepida, donec currat nutrimentum, et redeat ad figuram suam naturalem.	 "And apply embrocation to its wound with warm water continually, until the nourishment flows and it returns to its natural form.
¶ De curatione ossium fractorum quando restaurantur tortuose.	 "Regarding healing bone fractures when they are restored twisted.
Caput XXIII.	 Chapter 23.
Quando accidit membro iam restaurato post sanationem eius tortuositas, et eminentia ossi fracto, aut nodatio: et foedatur per illud forma membri, uerumtamen membrum non prohibetur ab operatione sua naturali: tunc non oportet ut recipias sermonem eius, qui existimat, ut frangatur membrum denuo.	 "When after the healing of a limb that has been restored and then shows twisting or prominence at the fractured bone or nodding, yet it is disfigured in form; however, the member does not prevent itself from its natural action: therefore, you should not accept the speech asserting that it will cause the body part to break again.
Et iam fuerunt multi stolidorum medicorum et restauratorum, qui fecerunt illud in terra nostra.	 "And there have been many foolish doctors and healers who have done this here on our land.
Et haec quidem operatio est uituperabilis ualde, perducens ad mortem, uel timorem magnum, ut scilicet sit mortalis.	 "And indeed, this operation is highly blameworthy and leads to death or great fear that it is mortal.
Verum si claudicatio et nodatio sunt recentes: tunc oportet, ut embrocetur cum aqua tepida, in qua decoctae sint herbae mollificantes, sicut folia alteae, et radix eius, et mellilotum, et illis similia.	 "However, if the limping and nodding are recent: then you should embrocate with warm water in which soaked herbs that soften have been cooked, such as leaves of yarrow, its root, and mallows, among others.
Et fiat ei emplastrum cum emplastro mollificatiuo, sicut dyachilon decenter factum.	 And let an ointment be made with a soothing plaster, as done with diachylon properly.
Aut sumatur mucilago radicis alteae, et concutiatur cum adipe gallinae, aut oleo sisamino: et emplastretur cum eo.	 Or be rubbed the mucilage of the root of althea and mixed with hen's fat or sesame oil; and it should be plastered with that.
Aut sumantur ficus pingues, et terantur cum fimo columbino, et similibus eis quae nominantur ex medicinis diminuentes consolidationem.	 Or take rubefacient figs and mix them with white clay from doves, and such things called medicines that reduce hardness.
Et quandoque soluitur nodatio cum fricatione assidua, antiqua, et leni, quae fit cum manibus humidis.	 And at times the knot is loosanno with constant, old-fashioned and gentle friction, which is done with moist hands.
Et administretur motus membri ad omnem partem in horis omnibus.	 And it should be administered movement to all parts of the limb at every hour.
Si autem tortuositas iam antecessit, et fortis facta est, et conuersa est in lapidem, et prouocata est necessitas ad curatonem eius cum ferro: tunc oportet, ut secetur superius eius, et soluatur continuatio ossis, et incidatur quod superfluit ex nodatione aut osse cum Incisoriis subtilibus: et administretur facilitas in illo cum sollicitudine et studio.	 But if the twist has already progressed, and it is strong and turned into stone, and there is a need for treatment with iron: then one should cut above that, and dissolve the continuation of the bone, and cut off what protrudes from the knot or bone with delicate incisors: and administer ease in that with carefulness and diligence.
¶ De sermone in Dislocatione.	 Of speech in dislocations.
Caput XXIIII.	 Chapter 24.
Dislocatio est exitus alicuius iuncturarum a loco suo.	 A dislocation is the outcome of certain joints being out of their place.
Quare prohibetur a motu suo, et foedatur figura membri.	 Why it prevents movement and spoils the figure of the limb.
Et facit accidere super infirmum dolores, et laesiones uehementes.	 And causes severe pain to occur in the weakened body, and acute injuries.
Quando ergo accidit alicui dislocatio, tunc oportet festinare ad restaurationem eius: neque tardet eam omnino.	 When therefore a dislocation occurs, then one must hasten to its restoration: do not delay it at all.
Nam si tardatur, apostematur locus, et fortasse cum eo reductio dislocationis.	 For if delayed, the place is inflamed and perhaps with it again bringing back of the dislocated bone.
Propter illud ergo non oportet, ut moueatur, neque extendatur in hora apostemationis eius.	 Therefore for this reason one should not move it, nor lengthen it at the hour of its inflammation.
Quoniam multotiens facit accidere spasmum, et dolores laedentes.	 For often it causes convulsions to occur, and injurious pains.
Verum quando accidit illud, tunc oportet, ut properes ad phlebotomiam infirmi.	 But when this happens, then one should hasten towards bleeding the sick person.
Deinde dimittatur, donec quiescat apostema.	 Then it is dismissed until the abscess rests.
Deinde embrocetur membrum cum aqua calida et oleo.	 Then the limb is bathed with warm water and oil.
Deinde reducatur cum facilitate.	 Then it is reduced with ease.
Et curetur omne membrum cum eo cuius rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	 And heal the entire limb as if nothing had happened.
Ego quidem iam ordinaui capitula dislocationis, etiam secundum quod praecessit in fractura, a superiori parte corporis usque ad inferiorem eius.	 Indeed, I have already set out chapters on dislocations, even as they occurred according to their position from the upper part of the body downwards.
